title: Bastard Rights and Restrictions
subtitle: Legal Standing of Noble-Born Illegitimate Children
content:
**Bastard Rights and Restrictions** defines the legal standing of children born out of wedlock to noble parents in [[Estargenn]]. This framework operates under [[The Proclamation on Noble Progeny Nomenclature]] and [[The Codified Charter of Driht, Ward, and Service]].

## Fundamental Principle

The core principle governing bastards:

> *"The blood of nobility shall not be wholly disavowed, yet neither shall it be placed equal to that which flows through lawful bonds of matrimony."*

Bastards are acknowledged as having noble blood but are distinguished from legitimate children in rights, obligations, and social standing.

## Rights of All Bastards

### What Bastards May Do

**Name and Identity**
- Bear the house surname with appropriate prefix ([[Dun-Names|Dun]] or [[Dum-Names|Dum]])  e.g., "Dunwilfrey" or "Dumwilfrey"
- Claim connection to the noble house
- Use house colors (though not always arms)
- Be identified as having noble blood

**Property and Livelihood**
- Own property in their own name
- Enter contracts and conduct business
- Inherit from non-noble relatives normally
- Receive gifts and bequests (at giver's discretion)
- Engage in trade or crafts
- Earn wages for service

**Legal Standing**
- Testify in courts (though weight of testimony may vary)
- Sue and be sued
- Make oaths (though they may be given less credence)
- Participate in legal proceedings

**Personal Life**
- Marry (subject to social constraints)
- Have legitimate children (who bear no bastard prefix)
- Travel freely within [[Estargenn]]
- Worship according to their conscience
- Join [[The Veritists]] if they pass the [[Verisol]]

**Service**
- Serve the noble house in various capacities
- Bear arms in defense of the house
- Hold household positions (steward, master of horses, etc.)
- Represent the house in matters where full authority not required

## Restrictions on All Bastards

### What Bastards May NOT Do

**Inheritance and Succession**
- Inherit titles or [[Driht]] authority by birth right
- Inherit property from the noble parent automatically
- Take precedence over legitimate children
- Assume they will be included in succession
- Demand equal share in division of estates
- Use the unprefixed house name (e.g., cannot call themselves "Wilfrey"  must use "Dunwilfrey" or "Dumwilfrey")

**Authority**
- Exercise [[Driht]] authority without explicit grant
- Command legitimate family members by birth right
- Represent the house in matters requiring full legitimacy
- Vote in councils reserved for legitimate members
- Hold certain offices reserved for lawful-born

**Heraldry and Honors**
- Bear undifferenced family arms (must use bastard marks)
- Use the full style of the house
- Claim honors belonging to legitimate heirs
- Assume courtesy titles

**Fealty**
- Receive [[Fealty]] oaths from others by birth right
- Hold wardship or custody without explicit grant
- Swear fealty on behalf of the house

## Difference by Prefix

### Dun-Named (Noble Father)

**Additional Rights:**
- Stronger claim to support from father's house
- More likely path to [[Legitimization]]
- Greater social standing
- More likely to hold household positions of trust

**Typical Expectations:**
- Service to the father's house
- Potential military career
- Possible marriage to lower nobility
- Some chance of legitimization if situation demands

### Dum-Named (Noble Mother)

**Additional Restrictions:**
- Weaker claim to support (mother's family may be embarrassed)
- Very rare path to [[Legitimization]]
- Lower social standing
- Often absorbed into lesser roles

**Typical Expectations:**
- Service in mother's household or elsewhere
- Often learns a trade or craft
- Marriage to commoners most likely
- Little expectation of elevation

## Obligations of Bastards

### To the House
- Loyalty to the noble house (not automatically enforced but expected)
- Not bringing shame upon the house name
- Serving when called upon (if receiving support)
- Maintaining the honor of the blood they carry

### To the Realm
- Same obligations as any subject of [[Estargenn]]
- Military service when levied (as commoners, unless specifically raised)
- Payment of taxes on any property owned
- Obedience to the [[Crown of Estargenn]]

## Obligations of Houses to Bastards

### Customary (Not Legally Required)
Noble houses typically:
- Provide some maintenance during childhood
- Offer education appropriate to station
- Arrange marriages when possible
- Find positions within the household
- Protect from serious harm

### Not Obligated To
- Treat bastards equally with legitimate children
- Include bastards in inheritance
- Publicly acknowledge bastards
- Provide for bastards beyond basic needs
- Legitimize bastards

## Record-Keeping

### Veritist Documentation
[[The Veritists]] record in [[Chronicle Chambers]]:
- Birth of bastards with circumstances (when known)
- The assigned prefixed surname (e.g., "Dunwilfrey" or "Dumwilfrey")
- The noble parent(s) involved
- Any subsequent [[Legitimization]] and restoration of unprefixed surname
- Deaths, marriages, and significant events

### Why Records Matter
Accurate records:
- Prove noble blood connection
- Document any changes in status
- Prevent fraud and false claims
- Preserve truth for historical purposes
- Support legitimization petitions when needed

## Social Realities

### The Bastard's Life
Despite legal framework:
- Treatment varies enormously by family
- Some bastards raised with legitimate siblings
- Others kept distant or hidden
- Personal relationships matter as much as law
- Luck and circumstance shape individual fates

### Paths to Advancement
Bastards may improve their standing through:
- [[Legitimization]] (when possible)
- Exceptional service earning honor
- Marriage improving station
- Wealth acquired through business or war
- Entry into [[The Veritists]] or religious orders
- Founding cadet branches (if legitimized)

## See Also
- [[The Proclamation on Noble Progeny Nomenclature]]: The foundational law
- [[Dun-Names]]: Bastards of noble fathers
- [[Dum-Names]]: Bastards of noble mothers
- [[Legitimization]]: Process of elevation

- [[The Codified Charter of Driht, Ward, and Service]]: Broader legal framework

title: Jon Wilfson
subtitle: Ninth Lord - The Present Day
content:
**Jon Wilfson** (b. 1953) is the current and ninth Lord of [[House Wilfson]], having succeeded his father [[Bauric Wilfson]] in 1985. He holds the hereditary titles of Drithling of House Wilfson, Master of the Silver Mines, and Castellan of [[Breakmount Castle]].

## The Inherited Position

Jon inherited a house fully restored to honor after seven generations of redemption following [[The Scandal of 1776]]. His father's marriage to [[Loveline Wilfson|Loveline]] of Breakmount had demonstrated that the kinslaying's stain had finally been erased.

## Marriage to House Dundas

Jon married [[Alisse Wilfson|Alisse]] of [[House Dundas]], a minor house. This practical match reflects the alternating pattern established after the scandal - prestigious Wilfrey alliance one generation, practical outside match the next.

## Children

- [[Baudin Wilfson]] (b. 2004) - heir, bearing the name finally reclaimed
- [[Saelind Wilfson]] (b. 2007) - daughter, named for her mother

## The Name Reclaimed

Jon named his heir Baudin - not Baudric, not Bauric, but **Baudin** itself. 250 years after [[The Scandal of 1776]], the original name is finally reclaimed:

- No longer feared as tempting fate
- No longer requiring a variant to soften its weight
- The name of the brother who died for love, spoken without shame

This represents the final healing of House Wilfson's ancient wound.

## Current Dignities

- **Drithling of House Wilfson** - sworn to the Paramount Driht of House Wilfrey
- **Master of the Silver Mines** - hereditary control of Breakmount's wealth
- **Castellan of Breakmount** - day-to-day governance of the principal seat

title: The Five Pillars of House Wilfrey
subtitle: The Core Values That Define Wilfrey Character
content:
The **Five Pillars** are the foundational principles that shape every Wilfrey, passed down through generations and reinforced through the [[The Fostering System|fostering system]]. They are not written law but lived practice - the bedrock upon which Wilfrey identity stands.

## The Pillars

### 1. Duty Before Desire

The Wilfrey way places obligation above personal want. This is not joyless sacrifice - it is the understanding that individual fulfilment comes *through* service to something larger, not despite it.

A Wilfrey does not ask "what do I want?" first. They ask "what is required of me?" And in meeting that requirement, they find their place, their purpose, their pride.

*This does not mean Wilfreys are unfeeling.* They love, they grieve, they rage. But they channel these through duty rather than letting them override it. The one who cannot master their heart masters nothing.

### 2. Blood and Bond

Family is everything - but family is more than blood.

The fostering system means that every Wilfrey heir grows up alongside their cousins from all four seats. They eat together, train together, learn together, form bonds that last lifetimes. A Wilfrey from [[Fourhearth Castle|Fourhearth]] has brothers at [[Bramblehall]], sisters at [[Riverhead]], kin at [[Breakmount Castle|Breakmount]].

This web of connection is deliberate. It prevents isolation. It makes the family resilient. When one seat falters, the others catch it. When one person wavers, the collective holds them steady.

**The lesson of [[House Wilson]] is taught as:** "This is what happens when we let one of our own stand alone. Let us be better."

### 3. The Weight of History

Wilfreys do not forget. They carry their history - triumphs and wounds alike - as a living inheritance.

The silver mines have flowed for generations. The fostering system has shaped centuries of heirs. The Wilson split remains an open wound, unhealed but not hidden. [[Baudin Wilfson|Baudin's]] choice is remembered. [[Colard Wilfson|Colard's]] terrible duty is honoured.

Every Wilfrey inherits all of this. The pride and the pain. The glory and the grief. To be Wilfrey is to accept this inheritance fully.

### 4. Loyalty Unbroken

[[House Wilfrey|House Wilfrey's]] commitment to the Crown of Estargenn is absolute. This is not blind obedience - it is principled allegiance, tested and proven.

The Crown accepted [[Lennis Wilfrey|Lennis]] and [[Nivette Wilfson|Nivette]]. The Crown established [[House Wilson]] on lands outside Wilfrey authority. The Crown holds, in its gift, the power to raise Wilson above Wilfrey should the family ever fall from favour.

**The Wilfreys know this.** They have always known it. And they remain loyal anyway.

This is the understanding that a great house does not break faith because faith might cost them. They are loyal because loyalty is *what they are*. The alternative - a Wilfrey who calculates when to be faithful and when to defect - is no Wilfrey at all.

### 5. Unity Over Self

When things go wrong, it is the family's failure, not merely the individual's. When things go right, it is the family's triumph, not merely the individual's.

A Wilfrey alone is vulnerable. A Wilfrey backed by the four seats, the cadet branches, the fostering bonds, the weight of history - that is strength that cannot easily be broken.

This is why the councils exist. This is why the fostering system exists. This is why the Wilfreys have endured when other houses have fallen. The whole is greater than its parts, and every part knows it.

title: The Wilfrey Voice
subtitle: How House Wilfrey Speaks - Formal Speech and Linguistic Character
content:
The **Wilfrey Voice** refers to the distinctive manner of speech that characterises [[House Wilfrey]] across all four seats. It is a style learned through the [[The Fostering System|fostering system]], refined through ceremony, and passed down through generations.

## Linguistic Character

Wilfrey speech is **formal but not flowery**. They use the old forms when appropriate, but they do not hide behind ornate language. There is a directness beneath the formality - a sense that words matter too much to waste on decoration.

### What Wilfreys Sound Like

- **Measured**: They do not rush. They choose words with care.
- **Direct**: They state hard truths plainly rather than softening them into meaninglessness.
- **Weighted**: Even simple statements carry the sense of history behind them.
- **Warm beneath formality**: The ritual language is not cold; it is how they express deep feeling *appropriately*.

### What Wilfreys Do NOT Sound Like

- **Boastful**: They do not list their achievements or demand recognition.
- **Flowery**: They do not pile adjective upon adjective or reach for elaborate metaphors.
- **Pleading**: They request, they do not beg. They state, they do not wheedle.
- **Cruel**: Even in judgement, there is gravity rather than malice.

## The Rhythm of Formal Speech

Wilfrey ceremonial language has a particular cadence:

- **Parallelism**: "In silver and in stone. In blood and in bond."
- **Triplets**: Three-part constructions feel natural and complete.
- **Call and Response**: Formal exchanges where one party speaks and another answers.
- **Witnessed Acts**: Important statements are made before witnesses and the act of witnessing is acknowledged.

### Examples

*Weak:* "We're here to witness this betrothal between these two people who are joining their houses together."

*Wilfrey:* "We stand as witnesses. Let what is spoken be remembered. Let what is promised be kept."

---

*Weak:* "I promise to be loyal to you and do my duty."

*Wilfrey:* "I pledge my faith. I pledge my service. I pledge my blood to your cause and my bones to your earth."

## Charter Language vs Personal Speech

The Codified Charter provides formal legal terminology: [[Driht]], [[Drihten]], [[Fealty]], [[Ward]]. This language should be used:

- In **formal ceremonies** (betrothals, investitures, oaths)
- In **legal contexts** (grants of land, judgements, formal declarations)
- When **invoking authority** (a lord speaking as lord, not as person)
- In **written records** meant for posterity

Charter language should NOT dominate:

- Informal conversation between family members
- Personal letters (though formal letters may use it)
- Internal thoughts or feelings
- Moments of genuine emotional breakthrough

**The principle:** Charter language is the voice of the institution. Personal language is the voice of the individual. Both are Wilfrey. Knowing when to use which is part of being Wilfrey.

## See Also

- [[Wilfrey Ceremonial Traditions]]: Where formal speech is most employed
- [[Wilfrey Correspondence]]: How voice adapts to written form
- [[The Codified Charter of Driht, Ward, and Service]]: Source of charter language

title: Wilfrey Ceremonial Traditions
subtitle: The Structure and Practice of Wilfrey Rites
content:
**Wilfrey ceremonies** follow patterns established over centuries, creating a sense that participants step into roles older than themselves. Every ceremony - from betrothal to investiture to funeral rite - shares common structural elements while adapting to specific purposes.

## The Five Elements of Ceremony

### 1. Opening (Gathering and Invocation)

The assembly gathers. The purpose is stated. Those present are acknowledged as witnesses. The weight of what is about to occur is established.

*Example:* "We gather in this hall where our fathers gathered. We speak words our fathers spoke. Let all present witness what transpires."

### 2. Declaration (The Core Purpose)

The central matter is stated plainly. What is being marked - a betrothal, an oath, a passing - is named without elaborate preamble.

### 3. Exchange (Oaths, Objects, Vows)

The active portion where binding words are spoken, objects are given, or physical acts are performed. This is where the ceremony does its work.

### 4. Witnessing (Acknowledgment)

Those present formally acknowledge what has occurred. The witnessing transforms a private act into a public one, binding the community to remember.

*Example:* "We have witnessed. We will remember. Let none say this did not occur."

### 5. Closing (Blessing and Charge)

The ceremony concludes with blessing for those involved and a charge to carry forward what has been established. Participants are released from the ritual space back to ordinary time.

## Historical Continuity

Every Wilfrey ceremony should feel like it has been performed before and will be performed again. The participants are not creating something new - they are stepping into ancient roles, adding their chapter to an ongoing story.

This is why the [[The Fostering System|fostering system]] teaches ceremonies from youth. By the time a Wilfrey leads a ceremony, they have witnessed dozens. The words feel familiar. The movements feel natural. The weight feels appropriate.

## Ceremony Types

- **Betrothals**: Witnessed promises between houses, sealed with exchange of tokens
- **Investitures**: Assumption of titles and responsibilities
- **Oaths of [[Fealty]]**: Binding of lord and vassal
- **Funerals**: The lighting of flames, the speaking of names, the commitment to memory
- **Council Openings**: Formal beginning of house deliberations

## The Role of Silence

In Wilfrey ceremony, silence is not empty. Pauses carry meaning. The moment before an oath is spoken, the quiet after a name is invoked for the last time - these silences are part of the ceremony, not interruptions to it.

title: The Wilson Wound
subtitle: The Unhealed Schism and Its Ongoing Impact
content:
**The Wilson Wound** refers to the ongoing emotional and political impact of the schism that created [[House Wilson]] approximately 250 years ago. While the historical events are documented elsewhere (see [[The Founding of House Wilson]], [[The Old Right]]), this entry addresses how the wound continues to shape [[House Wilfrey]] today.

## The Nature of the Wound

The Wilson split is not ancient history safely buried. It is:

- **An open question**: House Wilson exists. They share Wilfrey blood. They are not of the council. This ambiguity persists.
- **A cautionary tale**: Every generation learns what happens when the family fails one of its own.
- **A political vulnerability**: The Crown holds Wilson as a reminder that Wilfrey loyalty can be rewarded... or punished.
- **A personal grief**: Somewhere in every Wilfrey's lineage, someone loved [[Lennis Wilfrey|Lennis]] or [[Nivette Wilfson|Nivette]] or [[Baudin Wilfson|Baudin]] or [[Colard Wilfson|Colard]]. The loss echoes.

## How It Is Referenced

Wilfreys do not pretend the split didn't happen. Nor do they dwell on it. When it must be referenced:

- State the facts without editorial
- Do not relitigate or assign blame
- Do not pretend it didn't happen
- Move forward without lingering

*Example:* "House Wilson holds lands by the Crown's grant. They share our blood. They are not of our council."

That is enough. The silence around it says the rest.

## The Lesson Taught

To every generation of Wilfrey fosterlings, the Wilson story is taught as a lesson in unity:

**"This is what happens when we let one of our own stand alone. Let us be better."**

The emphasis is not on blame - not Lennis for loving, not the council for refusing, not Baudin for defending, not Colard for killing. The emphasis is on the collective failure that let it come to such a choice at all.

## Phrases That May Invoke It

- "We have learned, at great cost, the price of division."
- "The family endures. It has endured worse."
- "There are branches that have... grown apart."
- "Even brothers may stand on different sides of duty."
- "Some choices leave no one whole."

## Remembering Baudin and Colard

When the brothers must be spoken of, the [[The Wilfrey Voice|Wilfrey way]] is to acknowledge both with weight and sorrow:

*"Colard did what was required. Baudin paid what was owed. We remember them both."*

This is how Wilfreys honour tragedy - acknowledge the cost, honour the sacrifice, do not celebrate the violence, recognise that both brothers were trapped by circumstance.

## The Unspoken Hope

No Wilfrey speaks of reconciliation with House Wilson. The wound is too old, the separation too complete, the Crown's involvement too politically sensitive.

But in the silence, in the way the story is told as tragedy rather than triumph, in the emphasis on "let us be better" - there is the faintest acknowledgment that the wound might have been avoided. And if it might have been avoided, then perhaps, someday, in some form, it might be healed.

No Wilfrey says this. But the silence around it says something.

title: Wilfrey Correspondence
subtitle: The Art of Letters Across the Four Seats
content:
**Wilfrey correspondence** follows distinct conventions depending on the relationship between writer and recipient, the formality of the subject matter, and the purpose of the communication. Understanding these conventions is essential for any Wilfrey - and for those who would write to them.

## Three Registers of Correspondence

### Formal Letters

Used between houses, to the Crown, for official business, and for any matter that may become part of record.

**Characteristics:**
- Full titles and proper forms of address
- Charter language where appropriate ([[Driht]], [[Drihten]], etc.)
- Clear statement of purpose without preamble
- Formal closing with house words or appropriate blessing
- Sealed with house sigil

*Example Opening:* "From Aldric, [[Drithen]] of [[House Wilfrey of Riverhead|Riverhead]], to His Grace the High King - greetings and the loyalty of our house."

*Example Closing:* "Written at [[Riverhead]] under seal, in faithful service."

### Family Letters

Used between Wilfreys across the four seats, for matters both personal and political.

**Characteristics:**
- Appropriate titles but warmer tone
- Personal address permitted ("Cousin," "Brother in fostering," etc.)
- Business mixed with genuine inquiry about wellbeing
- Closing that acknowledges the bond
- May be sealed less formally

*Example Opening:* "To my fostering-brother Osric at [[Bramblehall]] - I hope this finds you well and the harvest abundant."

*Example Closing:* "Until we meet again at [[Breakmount Castle|Breakmount]], I remain your brother in all but blood."

### Intimate Letters

Used between close kin, spouses, or those with deep personal bonds.

**Characteristics:**
- May drop most formality
- Genuine emotion permitted and expected
- Still more structured than modern casual writing
- The relationship determines the warmth
- Often kept private, not for record

*Example:* "My heart - I count the days until your return. The children ask for you. Even the hounds seem to mope. Come home soon."

## The Art of Saying Without Saying

Wilfrey letters, particularly formal ones, often communicate through what they *don't* say:

- A letter that omits the usual pleasantries signals displeasure
- A letter that is shorter than custom expects suggests urgency or coldness
- A letter that includes unusual warmth may be preparing the recipient for difficult news
- A letter that mentions [[House Wilson]] at all is making a deliberate point

## Letters Across the Four Seats

Each seat has subtle variations in correspondence style:

- **[[Breakmount Castle|Breakmount]]**: Most formal, most careful with precedent
- **[[Bramblehall]]**: Simpler, more direct, less political calculation
- **[[Riverhead]]**: May include more practical/economic content
- **[[Fourhearth Castle|Fourhearth]]**: Most likely to include news from the wider world

## See Also
- [[The Wilfrey Voice]]: The speech patterns that inform correspondence
- [[The Five Pillars of House Wilfrey]]: Values expressed in written form
- [[The Codified Charter of Driht, Ward, and Service]]: Source of formal terminology

title: The Scandal of 1776
subtitle: Kinslaying, Exile, and the Birth of House Wilson
content:
The Scandal of 1776** was the defining crisis in [[House Wilfson]]'s history, resulting in the death of [[Baudin Wilfson]], the exile of [[Lennis Wilfrey]] and [[Nivette Wilfson]], the founding of [[House Wilson]], and the eternal marking of House Wilfson as kinslayers.

## Timeline of Events

### 1775 - Death of Lord Faramund
[[Faramund Wilfson]], Lord of House Wilfson, died peacefully after decades of faithful service. His eldest son [[Baudin Wilfson]] inherited the titles of Lord Wilfson, Master of the Silver Mines, and Castellan of [[Breakmount Castle]].

### 1776 - The Riverhead Council
The Lord of [[Riverhead]] died, triggering a mandatory council of all four lords. At this council, [[Lord Constann]] of [[Bramblehall]] raised the matter of his daughter [[Raylegh]]'s dishonor by [[Lennis Wilfrey]], heir to [[Fourhearth Castle]].

The council investigated and found:
- Raylegh had disguised herself as a serving wench
- She had deliberately sought out Lennis
- She was pregnant and betrothed to an elderly knight
- She had begged Lennis to marry her to escape her fate

The council's verdict: Lennis must marry Raylegh or lose his inheritance.

### Baudin's Defiance
[[Baudin Wilfson]], fostering brother to Lennis, publicly defied the council:
- Argued no council could command a man's heart
- Secretly arranged for his sister [[Nivette Wilfson]] to marry Lennis
- Performed the marriage in defiance of council authority

### The Kinslaying
When the secret marriage was discovered:
- All three were banished from House Wilfrey lands
- [[Colard Wilfson]], Baudin's younger brother, challenged him to a duel
- Colard's blade found Baudin's heart
- Baudin died having ruled less than two years

### The Aftermath
- Lennis and Nivette fled north, eventually founding [[House Wilson]] with royal favor
- Colard became Lord Wilfson, restoring the house to House Wilfrey's favor
- The kinslaying purchased 250 years of continued service
- House Wilfson became forever marked as both loyal servants and kinslayers

## The Legacy

The Scandal of 1776 is taught to every generation of fosterlings as both warning and lesson:
- The bonds of fostering can both unite and destroy
- Loyalty to the main house is rewarded with continuity
- Defiance, even for love, ends in death
- Some choices leave no one whole

title: Ermeline Wilfson

content:
**Ermeline Wilfson** (ne Wilfrey of Riverhead, 1726-1780) was the wife of [[Faramund Wilfson]] and mother of [[Baudin Wilfson]], [[Nivette Wilfson]], [[Adelise Wilfrey]], and [[Colard Wilfson]].

## Marriage Under The Old Right

Ermeline was a daughter of [[House Wilfrey of Riverhead]], given to House Wilfson under [[The Old Right]] practice - the ancient tradition where prominent cadet houses had rights to marry daughters of the ruling Wilfrey family.

## The Mother of Tragedy

Ermeline outlived her husband [[Faramund Wilfson]] by five years (d. 1780), long enough to witness:
- Her eldest son [[Baudin Wilfson]] defy the council for his fostering brother
- Her daughter [[Nivette Wilfson]] married in secret to [[Lennis Wilfrey]]
- Her younger son [[Colard Wilfson]] kill his brother in a duel
- Her daughter [[Adelise Wilfrey]] watch her family torn apart

She saw one son kill another. The weight of that witnessing can only be imagined.

## Legacy

Ermeline represents the human cost of [[The Scandal of 1776]] beyond the principals. While history remembers Baudin, Colard, and Nivette, it often forgets the mother who had to bury one son while knowing another had killed him.

title: Adelise Wilfrey
subtitle: The Sister Who Stayed
content:
Daughter of Faramund Wilfson. Married into House Wilfrey of Breakmount before The Scandal, maintaining a Wilfson connection
to the main house untainted by the kinslaying. Lived long and witnessed the aftermath. 

## The Fortunate Timing

Adelise married Aldric Wilfrey of Breakmount before the scandal erupted. When her brother [[Baudin Wilfson]] defied the council and was killed by [[Colard Wilfson]], Adelise was already safely established in the main house.

## The Untainted Connection

Adelise represented House Wilfson's continued presence within the Breakmount line:
- Not directly involved in the kinslaying
- Her children were Wilfreys, not Wilfsons
- A bridge between the disgraced cadet branch and the main house

## Witness to Aftermath

Adelise lived until 1815, witnessing:
- Her brother Baudin's death in 1776
- Her brother Colard's difficult reign as the Kinslayer
- Her nephew Baudric's controversial naming
- 39 years of House Wilfson's slow redemption

content:
**Giseline Wilfson** (ne Wilfrey of Bramblehall, 1758-1820) was the wife of [[Colard Wilfson]], the Kinslayer. Their marriage in 1778, two years after [[The Scandal of 1776]], was a gesture of reconciliation.

## A Marriage of Forgiveness

Giseline was born to [[House Wilfrey of Bramblehall]] - the very seat where [[Raylegh]]'s seduction of [[Lennis Wilfrey]] had occurred, triggering the entire scandal. Her marriage to Colard carried profound symbolic weight:

- Bramblehall had suffered embarrassment from the scandal originating at their seat
- By giving a daughter to the man who had restored House Wilfson's loyalty, they signaled forgiveness
- The marriage represented House Wilfrey's acceptance that Colard had done what was necessary

## Mother of the Redemption

Giseline bore Colard several children, including:
- [[Baudric Wilfson]] - heir, controversially named in memory of his slain uncle Baudin
- [[Farelin Goff]] - second son, married into House Goff
- [[Beraline Wilfern]] - daughter, married into House Wilfern

Through her children, she helped establish the new generation that would carry House Wilfson forward from the scandal.

## The Weight of Marriage

What was it like to be married to the man who had killed his own brother? The histories do not say. But Giseline remained with Colard for 42 years until her death in 1820, outliving him by eight years.

## See Also
- [[Colard Wilfson]]: Her husband, the Kinslayer
- [[Baudric Wilfson]]: Her eldest son
- [[The Scandal of 1776]]: The tragedy her marriage helped heal
- [[Bramblehall]]: Her birth house

title: Baudric Wilfson
subtitle: Third Lord - Named for the Slain
content:
**Baudric Wilfson** (1780-1848) was the third Lord of [[House Wilfson]], ruling from 1812 to 1848. His very name was controversial - a variant of [[Baudin Wilfson|Baudin]], the uncle his father had killed.

## The Controversial Name

[[Colard Wilfson]] named his heir Baudric - unmistakably derived from Baudin. This choice divided House Wilfson:

**Those who approved:**
- Saw it as honoring the dead
- Believed it showed Colard's guilt and desire for redemption
- Viewed it as keeping Baudin's memory alive

**Those who disapproved:**
- Called it tempting fate
- Saw it as inappropriate given the kinslaying
- Believed some names should be left to rest

Baudric himself never discussed the matter publicly. The weight of his name was his to bear alone.

## First Marriage Outside the Wilfrey Web

Baudric married [[Aveline Wilfson|Aveline]] of [[House Salter of the Scorch]] - the first Lord Wilfson since the scandal to marry outside the Wilfrey family network. This deliberate choice brought fresh blood after the trauma and began a pattern of alternating between Wilfrey marriages and outside alliances.

## Reign (1812-1848)

Baudric's 36-year reign was marked by:
- Steady, dedicated service to House Wilfrey
- Rebuilding trust after his father's necessary but damning act
- Establishing the pattern of alternating marriage alliances
- Raising children who would continue the redemption

## Children

- [[Coland Wilfson]] - heir, name echoing Colard (his grandfather)
- [[Ermette Wilfrey]] - daughter, married into House Wilfrey of Fourhearth
- [[Gisel Wilfson]] - son, became Fosterreeve for 30 years

## Legacy

Baudric represents the second generation after the kinslaying - born in its shadow, bearing a name that constantly reminded everyone of what had been lost, yet living a life of quiet redemption through service.

title: Coland Wilfson
subtitle: Fourth Lord - The Name Redeemed
content:
**Coland Wilfson** (1805-1878) was the fourth Lord of [[House Wilfson]], ruling from 1848 to 1878. His name was a variant of [[Colard Wilfson|Colard]] - the Kinslayer redeemed through generations of loyal service.

## The Name's Meaning

Three generations after [[The Scandal of 1776]], the name Coland/Colard had transformed:
- No longer just "the Kinslayer"
- Now also "the one who saved the house"
- A name that could be borne with a measure of pride

Coland represented the third generation - far enough removed that the stain had begun to fade, close enough that the lesson was not forgotten.

## Marriage to House Thornbury

Coland married [[Helewise Wilfson|Helewise]] of [[House Thornbury]] - a Drith-level landed family from the eastern reaches, known for horse breeding. This continued the pattern established by his father of seeking appropriate matches outside the immediate Wilfrey web.

title: Colwin Wilfson
subtitle: Fosterbookman - Keeper of Learning
content:
**Colwin Wilfson** (b. 1837) was the third child of [[Coland Wilfson]], his name a variant honoring his great-grandfather [[Colard Wilfson]] while remaining distinct. He never married and served as [[Fosterbookman]] in the fostering system.

## The Fosterbookman Role

The Fosterbookman directs all academic instruction within [[The Fostering System]]:
- Literacy, numeracy, history, heraldry, law
- Administrative knowledge expected of future lords
- Identifying individual talents for specialist instruction
- Maintaining teaching materials and educational records

## A Scholar's Life

Like his distant cousin [[Gisel Wilfson]], Colwin never married, devoting himself to scholarly pursuits and the education of noble youth. Two Wilfson men of different generations, both finding purpose in the fostering system rather than in continuing their own lines.

## The Name's Echo

Colwin's name echoed Colard - the Kinslayer. Yet by his generation, the name could be borne by a gentle scholar, a man who taught children rather than killed brothers. This transformation exemplifies House Wilfson's redemption.

Five generations after the scandal, Farmund's name connected directly to the pre-scandal era:
- Faramund had died peacefully, succeeded by Baudin
- Baudin's defiance led to the kinslaying
- By naming an heir Farmund, the family reached back to the time before the tragedy

## Marriage to House Cawdry

Farmund married [[Roseline Wilfson|Roseline]] of [[House Cawdry]], a minor house. This practical match reflected the reality of cadet house marriages:
- Not every generation could secure a prestigious Wilfrey alliance
- Minor house marriages maintained appropriate standing
- Economic and practical considerations balanced prestige

**Colbert Wilfson** (1885-1960) was the seventh Lord of [[House Wilfson]], ruling from 1932 to 1960. His name combined elements of both Colard and his father Berin - Colbert

## A Time of Stability

Six generations after [[The Scandal of 1776]], House Wilfson had achieved stability. The kinslaying was now distant history, and the house focused on its hereditary duties:
- Master of the Silver Mines
- Castellan of [[Breakmount Castle]]

## Marriage to House Parlin

Colbert married [[Maelisse Wilfson|Maelisse]] of [[House Parlin]], another minor house. Like his father's marriage to House Cawdry, this was a practical match maintaining appropriate standing for a cadet branch.

## Children

- [[Bauric Wilfson]] - heir, whose name would carry special significance
- [[Maeline Wentburn]] - daughter, married into House Wentburn
- [[Parris Wilfson]] - son, served as Fostersteward

## The Name Bauric

Colbert named his heir Bauric - yet another variant of Baudin. Seven generations after the kinslaying, the family was still honoring the slain brother. This persistence of memory demonstrates how deeply [[The Scandal of 1776]] marked House Wilfson's identity.

title: Bauric Wilfson
subtitle: Eighth Lord - Full Restoration
content:
**Bauric Wilfson** (1915-1985) was the eighth Lord of [[House Wilfson]], ruling from 1960 to 1985. His marriage to [[Loveline Wilfson|Loveline]] of [[House Wilfrey of Breakmount]] represented the full restoration of House Wilfson's position.

## The Restoration Marriage

Seven generations after [[The Scandal of 1776]], a daughter of the main Breakmount line was given to House Wilfson. This was not merely a practical alliance - it was a statement:

- House Wilfson was no longer marked by the kinslaying
- The generations of loyal service had earned full trust
- The premier cadet branch had truly been restored

The marriage to Breakmount - not Riverhead, not Bramblehall, not Fourhearth, but the **principal seat** - demonstrated that House Wilfson had emerged from the shadow of the scandal.

## Children

- [[Jon Wilfson]] - heir, current Lord
- [[Betts Wilfson]] - daughter, married into House Ironfell
- [[Lovine Ferncross]] - daughter, married into House Ferncross

## Legacy

Bauric's reign marked the culmination of seven generations of redemption:
- From kinslayer to trusted servant
- From scandal to restoration
- From stain to honor

The name Bauric - echoing Baudin - could finally be spoken without the weight of tragedy. The debt had been paid.

title: Baudin Wilfson (Heir)
subtitle: The Name Finally Reclaimed
content:
**Baudin Wilfson** (b. 2004) is the heir to [[House Wilfson]], son of [[Jon Wilfson]] and [[Alisse Wilfson]]. He is the first person in 250 years to bear the name Baudin without variant or alteration.

## The Name's Significance

250 years after [[The Scandal of 1776]], the name Baudin is finally reclaimed:

**The original Baudin** (1748-1776):
- Chose his fostering brother over council authority
- Died defending his sister's secret marriage
- His name became too heavy to speak directly

**The intervening generations** used variants:
- Baudric (3rd Lord)
- Bauric (8th Lord)

**Now, young Baudin** bears the full name:
- A sign that House Wilfson has fully processed the trauma
- No longer fearing the name as ill-omened
- Honoring the ancestor while looking forward

## The Weight of a Name

To be named Baudin Wilfson is to carry 250 years of history:
- The memory of a brother who chose love over duty
- The kinslaying that saved the house
- Seven generations of redemption
- The final healing of an ancient wound

Whether young Baudin feels this weight, or whether the name has finally become simply a name, remains to be seen.

title: House Wilson
subtitle: The Broken Branch
content:
Origins                                                                                                                    

House Wilson was founded in the aftermath of [[The Scandal of 1776]], when [[Lennis Wilfrey]] of Fourhearth and [[Nivette  
Wilfson]] fled north after her brother [[Baudin Wilfson]] was killed defending their secret marriage. They settled ~1778   
and received formal Crown recognition in 1785, establishing themselves outside Wilfrey authority entirely.                 

The Name                                                                                                                   

"Wilson" was deliberately chosen - close enough to "Wilfson" to honor their lineage, different enough to mark independence.
The founders never denied their Wilfrey blood; they simply proved that blood does not require submission.                 

Seat                                                                                                                       

[[Grantholm]] sits on a hill in the northern reaches, granted by royal charter. Unlike the four Wilfrey seats with their   
silver, timber, and trade, Grantholm's wealth comes from sheep and grain - modest but steady.                              

The Baudin Tradition                                                                                                       

Every firstborn son bears the name Baudin, honoring the brother who gave his life for the founders' marriage. The current  
lord, Baudin Wilson VII, is the eighth generation to carry the name. When asked, Wilsons say: "We remember Baudin. We      
always will."                                                                                                              

Motto                                                                                                                      

"The Crown only, may judge" - a pointed reminder that House Wilson answers to royal authority, not the Wilfrey council.    

Relations with House Wilfrey                                                                                               

For 250 years, the two houses have maintained cordial but distant relations. There has never been a marriage between them. 
Neither side has proposed reconciliation; neither would refuse if the other did.

title: Fosterheald
subtitle: Other Dignity
content:
The key leadership role for the Wilfrey fostering system. A role of high status within the wider Wilfrey houses and beyond. The Fosterheald serves as the supreme authority over House Wilfrey's fostering tradition - a role of profound cultural significance second only to the Breakmount Mine Master in institutional importance. This appointed position carries responsibility for shaping the character, loyalties, and capabilities of every noble child entrusted to Wilfrey care.
The Fosterheald determines curriculum, approves all staff appointments within the fostering system, mediates disputes between fosterlings, and maintains relationships with the families who have placed children in Wilfrey wardship. They hold the authority to discipline, recommend early release from fostering, or in extreme cases, petition for a fosterling's dismissal.
Traditionally, successful Fosterhealds have been drawn from former fosterlings themselves - individuals who experienced the system firsthand and emerged exemplifying Wilfrey values.

title: Fostermarshall
subtitle: Other Dignity
content:
The Fostermarshall bears responsibility for the martial education of all fosterlings under Wilfrey care. This encompasses instruction in mounted and unmounted combat, tournament preparation, tactical thinking, and the physical conditioning expected of nobility.
Beyond mere weapons proficiency, the Fostermarshall instills discipline, courage, and the warrior's code of conduct that fosterlings will carry into adulthood. They assess each fosterling's aptitudes and limitations, tailoring training accordingly while maintaining baseline standards all must meet.
The Fostermarshall coordinates closely with the Fosterbookman to ensure academic and martial schedules complement rather than conflict, and with the Fostersteward regarding equipment provisioning and training yard upkeep.

title: Fosterbookman
subtitle: Other Dignity
content:
The Fosterbookman directs all academic instruction within the fostering system - a role requiring both scholarly depth and pedagogical skill. Core curriculum includes literacy, numeracy, history, heraldry, law, and the administrative knowledge expected of future lords and ladies.
Beyond standard education, the Fosterbookman identifies individual talents and interests, arranging specialist instruction where warranted. A fosterling showing aptitude for cartography, medicine, or theological study might receive additional tutoring at the Fosterbookman's discretion.
The role also encompasses maintenance of teaching materials, correspondence with outside scholars, and careful record-keeping of each fosterling's academic progress - documents which follow them throughout life.

title: Fostersteward
subtitle: Other Dignity
content:
The Fostersteward ensures the practical machinery of the fostering system runs smoothly - a role encompassing housing assignments, meal provision, clothing, medical care, and the countless daily necessities fosterlings require.
This position demands diplomatic skill alongside administrative competence. The Fostersteward must balance the expectations of noble-born children accustomed to varying standards of living, manage the personal servants fosterlings bring from home, and maintain household harmony among young people from potentially rival families.
The Fostersteward also coordinates ceremonial occasions - feast days, arrival and departure ceremonies, and the formal events that mark a fosterling's progression through the system.

title: Fosterreeve
subtitle: Other Dignity
content:
The Fosterreeve manages all financial matters pertaining to the fostering system - a responsibility requiring both numerical precision and diplomatic discretion. Noble families pay varying amounts for their children's wardship, and the details of these arrangements remain strictly confidential.
Income streams under the Fosterreeve's management include fostering fees, equipment contributions, and occasional gifts from grateful families. Expenditures encompass staff wages, provisions, training equipment, educational materials, clothing allowances, and the countless incidental costs of maintaining noble youth in appropriate comfort.
The Fosterreeve maintains meticulous accounts separate from Breakmount's general ledgers, presenting regular reports to the Fosterheald and annual summaries to Lord Wilfrey. This financial independence ensures the fostering system remains self-sustaining and shields it from competing budgetary pressures within the wider household.
A skilled Fosterreeve anticipates needs before they become urgent - ensuring funds exist for replacing worn training equipment, expanding library holdings, or accommodating an unexpected influx of new fosterlings.

title: Fosterwarden
subtitle: Other Dignity
content:
The Fosterwarden holds dual responsibility as both security chief and deputy to the Fosterheald - a combination reflecting the role's origins in protecting valuable noble hostages during less peaceful times. In the Fosterheald's absence, the Fosterwarden assumes full authority over the fostering system.
Security duties encompass the physical safety of all fosterlings, staff, and visitors within fostering quarters. The Fosterwarden commands dedicated watchmen, controls access to sensitive areas, and coordinates with Breakmount's broader garrison during emergencies. When fosterlings venture beyond castle walls for training exercises or excursions, the Fosterwarden arranges appropriate escort.
Disciplinary authority represents the role's other major function. Minor infractions fall to individual staff members, but serious misconduct - fighting between fosterlings, theft, attempted escape, or behaviour bringing dishonour - comes before the Fosterwarden for investigation and judgment. They hold authority to confine fosterlings to quarters, assign punitive duties, or recommend more severe consequences to the Fosterheald.
The combination of security and discipline creates a figure fosterlings regard with healthy respect. A wise Fosterwarden balances firmness with fairness, understanding that today's wayward youth may become tomorrow's powerful ally.

title: Fostertallyman
subtitle: Other Dignity
content:
The Fostertallyman serves as the Fosterreeve's primary assistant in all matters of accounting - a position demanding meticulous attention to detail and absolute trustworthiness. Every transaction flowing through the fostering system passes through the Fostertallyman's ledgers.
Daily duties include recording expenditures, reconciling accounts, tracking inventory consumption, and maintaining the endless paperwork that financial management requires. The Fostertallyman ensures receipts are collected, payments documented, and discrepancies investigated before they compound.
Beyond mere record-keeping, an experienced Fostertallyman identifies patterns - noticing when equipment costs rise unusually, when certain suppliers offer poor value, or when consumption suggests waste or pilferage. These observations, reported to the Fosterreeve, enable proactive management.
The role serves as traditional training ground for those aspiring to reeve positions elsewhere. Many estates have welcomed Fostertallyman alumni into senior financial roles, their Wilfrey training considered mark of competence.

title: Fosterhirdward
subtitle: Other Dignity
content:
The Fosterhirdward manages the complex web of personal servants accompanying fosterlings from their home households - a role requiring equal measures of authority and tact. These attendants owe primary loyalty to their young masters and home houses, yet must operate within the fostering system's rules.
Coordination challenges abound. Personal servants may clash with fostering staff over proper procedures. Attendants from rival houses might carry family grudges into their daily interactions. Some fosterlings arrive with extensive retinues while others bring minimal staff, creating awkward disparities. The Fosterhirdward navigates all of this.
Practical responsibilities include housing assignments for attendants, establishing clear boundaries of authority, mediating disputes, and ensuring personal servants support rather than undermine the fostering system's educational goals. An attendant who helps their young lord evade training or smuggles forbidden items answers to the Fosterhirdward.
The role also monitors attendant welfare - these servants, often young themselves, are far from home serving masters who are themselves still children. A thoughtful Fosterhirdward recognises their vulnerability.

title: Fosterhorseward
subtitle: Other Dignity
content:
The Fosterhorseward bears responsibility for transforming noble children into confident riders - a fundamental skill expected of any wellborn adult. This encompasses basic horsemanship for newcomers, advanced riding for the competent, and mounted combat training for those approaching the end of their fostering.
Beyond instruction, the Fosterhorseward manages the horses dedicated to fostering use. Training mounts require particular temperaments - patient enough for beginners yet responsive enough to teach proper technique. The Fosterhorseward selects, maintains, and eventually retires these animals, always ensuring appropriate mounts exist for fosterlings of varying ages and abilities.
Coordination with Breakmount's main stables is essential but carefully boundaried. Fostering horses occupy dedicated stalls, and while farriers and veterinary care may be shared resources, the Fosterhorseward maintains independent authority over training schedules and horse assignments. Fosterlings who bring personal mounts from home present additional complexity - these animals must be evaluated, stabled appropriately, and integrated into training without disrupting established routines.
The Fosterhorseward also teaches horse care directly. Noble youth must understand grooming, feeding, tack maintenance, and the signs of illness or injury. A lord who cannot assess their own mount's condition is a lord poorly prepared for campaign or crisis.

title: Fosteredgemaster
subtitle: Other Dignity
content:
Oversees: Blade instruction, armoury management, equipment supply and maintenance
The Fosteredgemaster holds dual responsibility for weapons instruction and the physical tools of martial training - a combination recognising that excellence in blade work requires excellence in blade care. One cannot teach the sword without understanding the sword.
Instructional duties focus on edged weapons of all varieties. Longsword forms the foundation, but fosterlings receive exposure to shortswords, daggers, and polearms as appropriate to their age and aptitude. The Fosteredgemaster assesses each student's natural inclinations - some favour power, others speed, others precision - and shapes training accordingly while ensuring all meet baseline competency.
Armoury management represents equally vital responsibility. The Fosteredgemaster maintains the fostering system's dedicated store of training weapons, practice armour, and protective equipment. This includes wooden wasters for beginners, blunted steel for intermediate students, and properly weighted sparring weapons for advanced training. Every item requires regular inspection - a cracked waster or loose rivet invites injury.
Supply duties extend to coordinating with Breakmount's smiths and external suppliers. The Fosteredgemaster specifies requirements, evaluates quality, negotiates costs with the Fosterreeve's approval, and maintains inventory records. When fosterlings outgrow equipment or training demands expand, the Fosteredgemaster anticipates needs and requisitions accordingly.
A well-run armoury reflects its master. The Fosteredgemaster who tolerates rust, disorder, or ill-maintained equipment fails not only in duty but in the example set for students. Weapon care is weapon respect, and weapon respect underpins martial discipline.

**Type:** Minor House | **Founded:** ~1280 | **Motto:** "From Good Soil, Good Folk"

## Character
Practical, wealthy (by northern standards), and unpretentious. The Granfords are farmers first and lords second. Their lands are the most productive in the Northern Crown Marches.

## Economy
- Grain (wheat, barley, oats)
- Cattle
- Dairy

## Wilson Connection
Hamelina Granford married Baudin Wilson III (~1855). Hameline Wilson (daughter) married Tormund Granford (~1882), creating a double bond.

title: House Croftmoor
subtitle: Noble House
content:
**House Croftmoor** is a Northern Crown House seated at [[Moorstead]], in the remote moorlands.

**Type:** Minor House | **Founded:** ~1220 | **Motto:** "The Moor Endures"

## Character
Hardy, isolated, and self-sufficient. The Croftmoors live on the edge of civilization, wresting a living from the moors. They are known for their independence and their knowledge of moorland herbs and remedies.

## Economy
- Sheep (wool, mutton)
- Moorland herbs (medicinal trade)
- Peat

## Wilson Connection
Aureline Croftmoor married Baudin Wilson IV (~1885). Croftine Wilson (daughter) married Aldwin Croftmoor (~1916), strengthening the bond.

title: House Helmward
subtitle: Noble House
content:
**House Helmward** is a Northern Crown House seated at [[Helm Castle]], on the northern border.

**Type:** Minor House | **Founded:** ~1320 | **Motto:** "Vigilance and Valor"

## Character
Military, disciplined, and honorable. The Helmwards are border wardens, defending the northern marches against raiders and bandits. Every son learns the sword; every daughter learns to defend the walls.

## Economy
- Soldiers (mercenary contracts, Crown service)
- Smithing (weapons, armor)
- Some farming

## Wilson Connection
Doreline Helmward married Baudin Wilson V (~1918) - a later marriage, perhaps due to the wars of that era. Helmina Wilson (daughter) married Roderick Helmward (~1948).

title: House Blackmoor
subtitle: Noble House
content:
**House Blackmoor** is a Northern Crown House seated at [[Blackmoor Hall]], in the dark peatlands.

**Type:** Minor House | **Founded:** ~1050 | **Motto:** "We Keep the Old Ways"

## Character
Mysterious, insular, and traditional. The Blackmoors keep to old customs that others have forgotten. They are respected but not entirely trusted by their neighbors - though none can say exactly why.

## Economy
- Peat (fuel trade)
- Bog iron (low-quality but plentiful)
- Eel fishing

## Wilson Connection
Sireline Blackmoor married Baudin Wilson VI (~1948). Moraine Wilson (daughter) married Cedric Blackmoor (~1978).

title: House Stormcrest
subtitle: Noble House
content:
**House Stormcrest** is a Northern Crown House seated at [[Cresthold]], on the northern coast.

**Type:** Minor House | **Founded:** ~1400 | **Motto:** "Through Storm, Fortune"

## Character
Seafaring, adventurous, and cosmopolitan (by northern standards). The Stormcrests are fishermen and traders, their ships plying the northern waters. They bring news and goods from distant ports.

## Economy
- Fishing (sea fish, shellfish)
- Shipping (coastal trade)
- Salt (sea salt production)

## Wilson Connection
Eveline Stormcrest married Baudin Wilson VII (~1975), the current lord. Evelind Wilson (daughter) married Garrett Stormcrest (~2005).

title: House Thornwick
subtitle: Noble House
content:
**House Thornwick** is a Northern Crown House seated at [[Thornwick Manor]], the youngest of the northern houses.

**Type:** Minor House | **Founded:** ~1920 | **Motto:** "Rising Still"

## Character
Ambitious, aspiring, and eager to prove themselves. The Thornwicks were elevated to nobility only three generations ago, and they work hard to be accepted by the older houses. They are seen as social climbers, but capable ones.

## Economy
- Mixed farming
- Some trade
- Minor crafts

## Wilson Connection
Marelisse Thornwick married Baudin Wilson VIII (~2005), the current heir. This match elevated House Thornwick's status considerably.

title: House Ashford
subtitle: Noble House
content:
**House Ashford** is a minor Northern Crown House seated at [[Ashford Hall]].

**Type:** Minor House | **Founded:** ~1340 | **Motto:** "Steady as Stone"

## Character
Respectable, modest, and reliable. The Ashfords are minor gentry - not powerful, but well-regarded. They have held their small estate for centuries without distinction or disgrace.

## Economy
- Mixed farming
- Some forestry
- Local trade

## Wilson Connection
Rodric Ashford married Colardine Wilson (~1798), the first Wilson daughter to wed. House Ashford's acceptance of this match helped legitimize the exiled family among northern nobility.

title: House Fenwick
subtitle: Noble House
content:
**House Fenwick** is a small but ancient Northern Crown House seated at [[Fenwick Keep]].

**Type:** Minor House | **Founded:** ~980 | **Motto:** "Older Than Memory"

## Character
Ancient, proud of their lineage, and quietly dignified. The Fenwicks trace their line back to before the Wilfrey ascendancy. They are poor by lordly standards but rich in history.

## Economy
- Forestry (timber, hunting)
- Some farming
- Fur trade

## Wilson Connection
Aldric Fenwick married Lenniselle Wilson (~1805). The Fenwicks' ancient lineage accepting a Wilson bride reinforced that House Wilson was northern now, not Wilfrey.

title: Merehall
subtitle: Seat of House Northmere
content:
**Merehall** is the seat of [[House Northmere]], situated on the shores of the great northern lake.

## Architecture
A sprawling, low-built hall of grey stone, more longhouse than castle. The original structure dates back centuries, with additions built as needed rather than planned. Docks extend into the lake where fishing boats tie up.

## Surroundings
The great lake dominates the landscape - cold, deep, and rich with fish. Peat bogs stretch inland, providing fuel for the north. The Northmeres have fished these waters since before anyone kept records.

## Notable Features
- The Long Dock: Where the fishing fleet moors
- The Smoke House: Ancient structure for preserving fish
- The Peat Stores: Vast covered yards of drying peat

title: Wardkeep
subtitle: Seat of House Kingsward
content:
**Wardkeep** is the seat of [[House Kingsward]], a fortified garrison on the northern royal road.

## Architecture
A functional military fortress rather than a lordly castle. Square towers, thick walls, and a large gatehouse spanning the road. Designed to control passage, not to impress.

## Surroundings
Wardkeep straddles the northern royal road at a natural chokepoint between hills. All traffic north or south must pass through its gates and pay its tolls.

## Notable Features
- The King's Gate: Main passage through, tolls collected here
- The Garrison Yard: Barracks for Crown soldiers
- The Road Tower: Watchtower with views for miles in each direction

title: Granford Keep
subtitle: Seat of House Granford
content:
**Granford Keep** is the seat of [[House Granford]], surrounded by the richest farmland in the Northern Crown Marches.

## Architecture
A practical, well-maintained keep with extensive outbuildings - barns, granaries, and cattle sheds. The Granfords invest in their farms, not their walls.

## Surroundings
Rolling fields of wheat, barley, and oats stretch to the horizon. Fat cattle graze in meadows. This is the breadbasket of the north - modest by southern standards, but vital up here.

## Notable Features
- The Great Granary: Stores enough grain to feed the northern houses through hard winters
- The Cattle Fair: Annual market drawing buyers from across the region
- The Mill: Water-powered, grinding grain for the whole district

title: Moorstead
subtitle: Seat of House Croftmoor
content:
**Moorstead** is the seat of [[House Croftmoor]], a remote stronghold on the edge of the northern moors.

## Architecture
A squat, weathered tower surrounded by a low wall - built to endure harsh conditions rather than siege. Outbuildings cluster close for protection from the wind.

## Surroundings
Endless moorland stretches in all directions - heather, gorse, and rough grass. Sheep dot the landscape. The wind never stops. It is beautiful in a bleak way, and deeply isolated.

## Notable Features
- The Herb Garden: Walled enclosure where moorland medicinals are cultivated
- The Sheep Folds: Stone enclosures dotting the moors for miles
- The Signal Tower: For communicating across the vast moorland distances

title: Helm Castle
subtitle: Seat of House Helmward
content:
**Helm Castle** is the seat of [[House Helmward]], a border fortress in the northern marches.

## Architecture
A true military castle - high walls, strong towers, and a well-designed killing ground before the gates. The Helmwards have defended this border for generations and their home reflects it.

## Surroundings
Rocky, defensible terrain on the edge of settled lands. Beyond lies wilderness - and whatever threats emerge from it. The castle watches the passes and guards the approaches.

## Notable Features
- The Armoury: One of the finest collections of weapons in the north
- The Training Yard: Where every Helmward child learns the sword
- The Watch Fires: Beacon system to warn of approaching threats

title: Blackmoor Hall
subtitle: Seat of House Blackmoor
content:
**Blackmoor Hall** is the seat of [[House Blackmoor]], rising from the dark peatlands of the northern bogs.

## Architecture
An ancient hall built on an island of solid ground amid the bogs. Dark stone, small windows, and a perpetual smell of peat smoke. The approach is treacherous to those who don't know the paths.

## Surroundings
Black water, dark peat, and grey mist. The bogs are dangerous but productive - peat for fuel, bog iron for smithing, eels for eating. The Blackmoors know every safe path; outsiders frequently don't.

## Notable Features
- The Bog Paths: Secret routes known only to the family and trusted servants
- The Iron Pits: Where bog iron is harvested and smelted
- The Old Shrine: Ancient stones predating the hall, still honored with offerings

title: Cresthold
subtitle: Seat of House Stormcrest
content:
**Cresthold** is the seat of [[House Stormcrest]], perched on cliffs overlooking the northern sea.

## Architecture
A windswept castle built into the cliff face, with a protected harbor below. Salt-stained stone and iron-bound doors that can withstand the worst storms. Ships are as important as walls here.

## Surroundings
The northern sea - grey, cold, and full of fish. Rocky coastline with hidden coves. The Stormcrests know every inlet and current along this stretch of coast.

## Notable Features
- The Harbor: Protected anchorage carved from the cliff base
- The Salt Works: Where sea water is evaporated for salt
- The Trader's Hall: Where goods from distant ports are bought and sold

title: Thornwick Manor
subtitle: Seat of House Thornwick
content:
**Thornwick Manor** is the seat of [[House Thornwick]], the newest of the Northern Crown Houses.

## Architecture
A comfortable manor house rather than a castle - the Thornwicks were elevated to nobility only three generations ago and their home reflects their origins as wealthy farmers. Well-built but unpretentious.

## Surroundings
Good farmland, some woodland, a village of tenants. Nothing remarkable, but solid and productive. The Thornwicks are still building their legacy.

## Notable Features
- The New Hall: Recently expanded great hall, eager to host important guests
- The Orchards: Apple and pear trees, a point of pride
- The Village: Prosperous tenants who remember when the Thornwicks were just farmers like them

title: Ashford Hall
subtitle: Seat of House Ashford
content:
**Ashford Hall** is the seat of [[House Ashford]], a modest manor near a river crossing.

## Architecture
A comfortable old hall, neither grand nor decrepit. The Ashfords have held this land for centuries, maintaining it without expanding it. The hall looks much as it did generations ago.

## Surroundings
Mixed farmland along a small river. An old stone bridge gives the place its name - "ash ford" from the ash trees that once lined the crossing. Pleasant, unremarkable country.

## Notable Features
- The Old Bridge: Stone crossing that has stood for centuries
- The Ash Grove: Replanted after the original trees died, maintaining tradition
- The Family Chapel: Small but ancient, with Ashford tombs dating back generations

title: Fenwick Keep
subtitle: Seat of House Fenwick
content:
**Fenwick Keep** is the seat of [[House Fenwick]], an ancient tower in the northern forests.

## Architecture
A single tall tower of old stone, surrounded by wooden outbuildings. The keep predates written records - the Fenwicks claim it was ancient when their ancestors first held it. It has been repaired but never expanded.

## Surroundings
Dense forest - oak, ash, and pine. Hunting grounds that have provided for the Fenwicks for longer than anyone remembers. The trees press close, and the keep feels hidden from the world.

## Notable Features
- The Ancient Tower: Original structure of unknown age
- The Hunting Lodge: Deep in the forest, where the lords stay during long hunts
- The Fur Store: Where pelts are prepared for trade
